It is considered one of the oldest rainforests in the world, with an estimated age of over 180 million years. The Daintree Rainforest is home to a wide variety of plant and animal species, many of which are found nowhere else on Earth.

The climate of the Daintree Rainforest is tropical, with a wet season from November to April and a dry season from May to October. During the wet season, the forest receives a significant amount of rainfall, which supports the growth of lush vegetation. The dry season, on the other hand, is characterized by lower rainfall and drier conditions, which can affect the growth and survival of certain plant and animal species.

The soil in the Daintree Rainforest is nutrient-poor and acidic, which can limit the types of plants that can grow in the area.
